Following lunch, on Jan. 27th, we toured the Belle Meade Historic Site and Winery.  Of the three mansions that we toured in Nashville, this was the most expensive and the least interesting, although still worth touring  - to us, at least - .  Like The Hermitage, no photography was allowed in the house.  The tour did include a wine tasting but the samples were small and we found the wine both very expensive and not to our taste.In the mid 19th century, Belle Meade encompassed roughly 5,400 acres with over a hundred enslaved persons.  Today, this historic house is now operated as an attraction, museum, winery, and onsite restaurant on its 30 acres of property.  Preserved original outbuildings, include the original Harding Cabin where Belle Meade began, a dairy, a gardener - s house, a carriage and stable house, one of the largest smokehouses in Tennessee, and a mausoleum.Belle Meade had many successful thoroughbred studs, including Bonnie Scotland and Enquirer, whose bloodlines long dominated racing in America. Jackson attracted international fame in 1886 by buying the stallion Iroquois to stand at stud; the horse was ranked in 1892 as the leading sire in the United States.Read more
